structural_unit_name.en: Johan Skytte Institute of Political Studies

description.en:
The course provides a critical overview of the main theoretical approaches to the European Union and the process of European integration, with an emphasis on contemporary political science theories. The EU has been widely regarded as a social science puzzle because it does not fit neatly into existing conceptual categories and disciplinary divisions. Scholars disagree about whether theories located in the International Relations or Comparative Politics discourses are better equipped to explain European integration; these tensions are also reflected in the rivalry between intergovernmentalist approaches and theories of supranational governance. In addition to these, the course covers a variety of other approaches from the three pre-theories (federalism, functionalism, and transactionalism) to neofunctionalism, the debate between liberal intergovernmentalism and supranationalism, neoinstitutionalism, constructivism and theories of Europeanization. Our discussion of the theories of integration focuses on four central questions:
1.	What is the EU (an international organization, a technocratic regime, a form of intergovernmental cooperation, a supranational state-like entity, a federation)?
2.	How does integration proceed and who or what drives integration (member-state governments, supranational institutions, interest groups, etc)?
3.	What patterns of interaction and influence characterize the relationship between the EU and the member states?
4.	How will the EU continue to evolve in the future and what does the European experience tell us about regional integration and supranational governance in general?

In terms of teaching and learning formats, the course emphasizes academic writing and is designed to prepare students for writing an MA thesis (especially the theoretical sections of the thesis).
description.et:
Kursus annab ülevaate peamistest teoreetilistest lähenemistest Euroopa Liidule ja eurointegratsioonile rõhuasetusega tänapäevastel politoloogilistel käsitlustel. 
Euroopa Liitu on nimetatud sotsiaalteaduste suureks mõistatuseks, kuna ta ei sobitu selgepiiriliselt  olemasolevatesse kontseptuaalsetesse kategooriatesse. EL asub rahvusvaheliste suhete ja võrdleva politoloogia ristumispunktis, kus omavahel võistlevad valitsustevaheline lähenemine (intergovernmentalism) ja rahvusülese valitsemise teooriad (supranational governance). Lisaks eelmainitutele leiavad kursuse raames käsitlemist mitmed teised suunitlused, alates funktsionalismist kuni ratsionaalse valiku, kahetasandiliste mängude, mitmetasandilise valitsemise ning konstruktivistlike teooriateni. Kursus
keskendub kolmele põhilisele küsimusele:
1) Mis on Euroopa Liit (rahvusvaheline organisatsioon, tehnokraatlik režiim, valitsustevahelise koostöö vorm, rahvusülene riigilaadne süsteem, föderatsioon, jne)?
2) Kuidas toimub Euroopa integratsioon ning kes või mis on integratsiooni mootoriks (liikmesriikide valitsused, rahvusülesed institutsioonid, jne)?
3) Millises suunas Euroopa Liit areneb ning mida võime Euroopa näite varal järeldada regionaalse integratsiooni ja/või globaalse valitsemise kohta laiemalt?

objectives.en: The overarching objective of the course is to offer a comprehensive overview of the main theoretical approaches to the European Union and the process of regional integration. A critical engagement with the ideas, concepts, and theories that have been developed to describe and explain far-reaching regional integration in Europe enables us to gain a deeper understanding of what the European Union is, how it works, how it came about, and how it might develop in the future. Studying theories of European integration also makes us better equipped to answer the question of whether and how comparable levels of regional integration could be reached in other parts of the world.
objectives.et: Kursuse eesmärk on anda ülevaade peamistest teoreetilistest lähenemistest Euroopa Liidule ja eurointegratsioonile.

notes.et: In case class meetings at the UT are suspended due to risks associated with COVID, the course will switch to online mode.

independent_work.et:
Three short writing assignments: Students are required to write three very short papers (1000-1200 words or about 2 pages each, font 11, Times New Roman) for selected seminars. The papers serve two objectives: a) they help ensure everyone is prepared for the seminar discussions and b) they help you practice specific writing and research skills, such as effective paragraph-level writing, summarizing a (set of) research article(s), characterizing a body of literature, and connecting theory and case by spelling out the observable implications of the theory. Detailed instructions -- see syllabus and Moodle.

Research proposal: Students are required to write a research proposal that discusses/interprets a concrete event, case, development or puzzle in European integration in light of one or several theoretical approaches covered in the framework of this course. Note that a research proposal is a carefully designed, elaborate PLAN for conducting a theoretically-informed empirical investigation. In other words, you do not have to do any actual empirical analysis (collecting or analyzing data) for this assignment, nor are you expected to provide an answer to the research question you pose. However, the project that you propose should be realistic and in principle, doable. Detailed written guidelines for preparing the research proposal, along with assessment criteria,  will be posted on Moodle. Late papers will lose 1.5 points per day (out of a maximum of 35 points). Format: Times New Roman, font 12, spacing 1.5; suggested length: 8-10 pages (including a list of sources).

description.et:
Writing assignment 1 (5% of the grade): Write a short paper (2 pages) that  makes three important points about neofunctionalism. The paper should consists of three excellent paragraphs (that follow the rules of paragraph writing introduced in class). The assignment is designed to help you practice paragraph-level writing as well as the art of characterizing a body of literature.
Additional guidelines are available on Moodle.

Participation in a debate (5% of the grade). There will be a debate focusing on the question "Do member state governments control the process of European integration?" Group A will defend the position that they do, while Group B will argue that they do not. Members of each group have to work together before the debate to prepare their positions. During the debate, each group will advance its arguments and defend its positions. 
The format of the debate is as follows:
Each group will choose a proposer, a seconder, and someone to make a concluding statement.
The debate will begin with a proposing statement (10 minutes) and seconding statement (5 minutes) by Group A, followed by similar statements by Group B. This will be followed by a 'plenary' debate open to all members of the groups (35 minutes). After this, the groups will have 15 minutes to prepare their concluding statements. The debate ends with both groups presenting their concluding statements (a 10 minutes). Note that the concluding statements must be based on points made during the debate and should not be pre-prepared.
Additional guidelines for the debate will be available on Moodle.

Writing assignment 2 (5% of the grade): Practice applying a theory to a case by first providing a succinct summary of how rationalism and constructivism explain the decision to enlarge, followed by a (bullet-pointed) list of the observable implications of each theoretical approach (max 2 pages) for this particular case. In other words, what should we be able to observe if the LI, SG or constructivist account of EU enlargement is accurate? 
Additional guidelines are available on Moodle.

Writing assignment 3 (5% of the grade) Find an academic article that uses the framework of Europeanization to analyze a particular policy area in (a) particular country/countries. Write a 1-2 page summary of the article, using the template provided (theory/data/case/method/results/ assessment). The assignment, together with the seminar discussion, allows you to hone the skill of summarizing and reviewing a body of empirical research.
Additional guidelines are available on Moodle.

Submit a 1-2 page initial outline of your research proposal via . Describe your idea: what theory do you plan to use, what is the case that you apply it to? The outline will not be graded but I will provide feedback on your idea.

The final exam is closed-book written exam lasting up to 2 hours. The exam includes both short-answer questions (definitions, identification questions) as well as questions that require a longer answer in which you synthesize and assess material covered in the course. The exam focuses on the theories of integration as well as the historical context in which these theories arose. A study guide will be provided at least two weeks in advance. The exam gives a maximum of 45 points (45% of the course grade)

Research proposal: Students are required to write a research proposal that discusses/interprets a concrete event, case, development or puzzle in European integration in light of one or several theoretical approaches covered in the framework of this course. Note that a research proposal is a carefully designed, elaborate PLAN for conducting a theoretically-informed empirical investigation. In other words, you do not have to do any actual empirical analysis (collecting or analyzing data) for this assignment, nor are you expected to provide an answer to the research question you pose. However, the project that you propose should be realistic and in principle, doable. Detailed written guidelines for preparing the research proposal will be distributed in class and posted on Moodle. Late papers will lose 1.5 points per day (out of a maximum of 35 points). Format: Times New Roman, font 12, spacing 1.5; suggested length: 8-10 pages (including a list of sources).

grade_preconditions.et:
The final grade for the course consists of the following components: 
- Contribution to the debate (5% of the grade)
- Three short writing assignments (each worth 5% of the grade, total 15 %) 			
- Final exam (45%)				
- Research proposal (35%)

grade_evaluation.et:
The final grade for the course consists of the following components: 
- Contribution to the debate (5% of the grade)
- Three short writing assignments (each worth 5% of the grade, total 15 %) 			
- Final exam (45%)				
- Research proposal (35%)

debt_elimination.et:
Exam times are fixed. Make-ups are scheduled only in extraordinary, documented circumstances (e.g. serious illness).
Research proposals are accepted after the deadline but will lose 1.5 points per day (out of a maximum of 35 points).

assessment_scale.et: Eristav (A, B, C, D, E, F, mi)
assessment_scale.en: differentiated (A, B, C, D, E, F, not present)

description.et: Introduction. Introduction, aims and organization of the course. What is a theory, why do theories matter and what criteria should we apply when assessing theories? Required readings: see Moodle. .

Key debates in theories of European integration. A roadmap for the course What kind of animal is the EU? How did it evolve? Which theories and debates will be covered in this course, and is there method to the madness (how can one make sense of all these "-isms"?)?. Three big debates: IR vs CP; rationalism vs constructivism; MS governments vs supranational institutions. Required readings: see Moodle. .

The structure of the post-WWII academic debate: federalism, functionalism, transactionalism What are the main claims and assumptions underlying each of the so-called pre-theories of integration? What do they have in common, and where do the three diverge? To what extent are the pre-theories political programmes as opposed to academic theories? What developments on the ground are consistent with each approach? Required readings: see Moodle. .

Seminar: Neofunctionalism vs intergovernmentalism What does the theory of NF argue, and how does it differ from functionalism? What is spillover and why does it occur? Describe, compare and contrast NF and early intergovernmentalism: what are the questions they are asking, how are they trying to answer these, and who do they consider to be the main players? Why was NF declared obsolete in the mid-1970s? Required readings: see Moodle. WRITING ASSIGNMENT 1 DUE. Write a short paper (1.5 -2 pages) that makes three important points about neofunctionalism. The paper should consists of three excellent paragraphs (that follow the rules of paragraph-level writing introduced in class). The assignment is designed to help you practice paragraph-level writing as well as the art of characterizing a body of literature. .

Liberal Intergovernmentalism After decades of limited progress and "eurosclerosis," the project of European integration acquired new momentum under Commission President Jacques Delors and with the conclusion of the Singe European Act (1986). This prompted new theorizing about European integration. Why do sovereign states voluntarily pool sovereignty in supranational institutions? Do they retain control over the process of integration? The explanation provided by Andrew Moravcsik in his seminal book (1998) became a focal point for these debates. What are Moravcsik's main arguments? What is "liberal" about LI? What are the three stages of his "tripartite analytical framework"? What happens at each stage? How does LI explain the emergence and considerable powers of supranational institutions? Required readings: see Moodle. .

Supranational governance Moravcsik had many critics. Most prominent among those were the representatives of the supranational governance approach. They argued that major policy reforms in EC/EU were initiated and led by supranational institutions (mostly the Commission acting in tandem with the Court) who responded to societal need for European-level rules and regulation. This approach pays great attention to market liberalization that occurred after the adoption of the Single European Act: in a number of policy domains, such as telecommunications, air transportation, postal and broadcasting services, etc, powerful national monopolies were dismantled and markets were opened up to competition. Market liberalization/de-regulation has been followed by re-regulation at the European level.The creation of supranational policy regimes has, in turn, strengthened the EU's supranational actors who have become managers and guardians of the new order. Please consider: what advantages do supranational actors have over governments? Can you trace continuities from earlier approaches (especially transactionalism and neofunctionalism)? Why is supranational governance sometimes referred to as neo-neofunctionalism? What are the main points of contestation between SG and LI? What are the limitations of this debate? Required readings: see Moodle. .

Neoinstitutionalism In what ways do "institutions matter"? How does new institutionalism differ from old institutionalism and what are its main tenets? Note that there are three strands of neoinstitutionalism. What are they and how do they differ from one another? Required readings: see Moodle .

Debate: Do member state governments control the process of European integration? Group A will defend the position that they do, while Group B will argue that they do not. Members of each group have to work together before the debate to prepare their positions. During the debate, each group will advance its arguments and defend its positions. The format of the debate is as follows: Each group will choose a proposer, a seconder, and someone to make a concluding statement. The debate will begin with a proposing statement (10 minutes) and seconding statement (5 minutes) by Group A, followed by similar statements by Group B. This will be followed by a 'plenary' debate open to all members of the groups (35 minutes). After this, the groups will have 15 minutes to prepare their concluding statements. The debate ends with both groups presenting their concluding statements (a 10 minutes). Note that the concluding statements must be based on points made during the debate and should not be pre-prepared. No prescribed literature for the debate, you are free to rely on whatever sources you deem relevant. .

Social constructivism What are the main assumptions and arguments associated with the constructivist approach in international relations? How, and with what effects, have these been applied to the EU? Constructivism emphasizes the role of identities and ideas. What does this contribute to our understanding of the EU? Required readings: see Moodle. .

Seminar: Explaining the decision to enlarge Which theoretical approach - rationalism or constructivism -- can best explain the EU's decision to admit 10 new countries in 2004? Writing assignment 2 DUE : Practice applying a theory to a case by writing a short paper (max 2 pages) that first provides a succinct summary of how rationalism and constructivism explain the decision to enlarge, followed by a (bullet-pointed) list of the observable implications of each theoretical approach for this particular case. Observable implications are things we would expect to observe in the real world if our theory is right. In other words, what should we be able to observe if the rationalist/ constructivist account of EU enlargement were accurate? Bring the paper to class and hand it in. Keep following the rules of paragraph-level writing that we practiced earlier. Note that the focus of this assignment is on why the EU was willing to enlarge (take in relatively poor Eastern European countries), as opposed to why the candidate countries wanted to join (or any other aspect of enlargement). Keep this focus, do not veer off course. The required texts for the assignment are listed below. You are free to use additional sources, if you want (but don't have to). When thinking about observable implications, it is probably best to rely on your own brain (as opposed to the internet). After you have read the texts below, set them aside, and think (i.e. ask yourself: what kind of evidence would lend support to the rationalist/constructivist explanation of why the EU decided to enlarge?) Format of the seminar: discussion in groups, focusing on the question provided above, followed by a brief presentation by each group. .

Theories of Europeanisation How does the EU influence the member states? What kind of changes at the national and subnational level occur because of EU membership? What are the main research questions posed by the Europeanization literature? What answers does it provide? Why is it often claimed that Europeanization is not a theory but an analytical framework? What is meant by uploading and downloading? What is "goodness of fit" and why does it matter? Required readings: see Moodle. .

Seminar: Examples of Europeanization research Writing assignment 3 DUE! Find an academic article that uses the framework of Europeanization to analyze a particular policy area in (a) particular country/countries. Write a 1-2 page summary of the article, using the template provided (theory/data/case/method/results/ assessment). The assignment, together with the seminar discussion, allows you to hone the skill of summarizing and reviewing a body of empirical research. The format of the seminar is discussion in groups, focusing on the following questions: How do these authors apply Europeanization to a particular case? With what results? What kind of conceptual, empirical or methodological problems did they face and how did they overcome these? What are the common themes, problems in the literature you read? What lessons do you derive from this exercise? .

The comparative and governance turns in EU studies: the EU as a (federal) political system and as a system of multi-level governance BRIEF OUTLINE OF RESEARCH PROPOSAL (2 PAGES) DUE. Has the EU become integrated to the extent that it can now be considered a normal polity and compared to other federal states? Can we apply regular comparative politics theories to the EU and what do we gain by doing so? What is the value of studying the EU through the lens of the governance approach? Is politicization the right cure for the EU? Why/why not? Required readings: see Moodle. .

Politicization of European integration, impact of crises, critical approaches. Have the multiple crises in the EU stimulated new thinking and new approaches to grand and middle-ranged theory? Has European integration become politicized to the extent that it now constitutes a new political cleavage in European societies? Who or what drives politicization, and what does increased political contestation imply for the future of the EU? Finally, what critical perspectives are out there, and how seriously should we take their arguments? .Required readings: see Moodle. .

Regional integration in a comparative perspective. Summary assessment & concluding remarks. Preparation for the final exam. What is the state of other regional integration projects around the world? How are these similar to and different from the European one? What factors account for this such variation? Can we use the same theories and methods to study regional integration in different parts of the world? Should we expect to see more or less regional integration in the future? What have we learned from theories of integration? What have these omitted; what new approaches are out there? Required readings: see Moodle. .
Final exam. A two-hour written exam. A study guide will be provided at least two weeks before the exam.
